item.description:
The context is this: I wrote this poem as an extension of my emotions 10 years ago. The poem’s titled “Satya” and was the first poem on my blog.

It triggered something that was already brewing inside me vehemently, into words. This is my commentary on my own writing after 10 years of seeking, learning, and coming home.

The context is this: I wrote this poem as an extension of my emotions 10 years ago. The poem’s titled “Satya” and was the first poem on my blog.

Neither am I a poet, nor a storyteller. I wrote what I genuinely felt at that time. And this was close to when Gadhimai Mela was about to happen and there was a lot of news about Bali Pratha needing to stop and so on. It triggered something that was already brewing inside me vehemently, into words. This is my commentary on my own writing after 10 years of seeking, learning, and coming home.

I will explain each paragraph one by one: what still is true, what I have learned that I didn’t a decade ago, and so on. This will probably be a long one, but a worthy one if you genuinely are looking for yourself too. And I don’t think I will write much on Spirituality from now on because my path is laid somewhere else. And there is more than enough written out there for an ardent seeker already.

I am just enjoying living. If you have questions, you can personally ask me. No time for arguments, all the time for those who truly need it. Apart from that, I hope you find peace within you. I bow down to the divinity in all of you. Lets get started here:

आकाङ्क्षाका पानाहरुमा
समेटिएको यो जीवनमा
च्यातिएका ती पानाहरु
स्वयमहित्को तान्डवसँगै
कुल्चिएका भावनाहरु ।

The wise ones say the Universe was born out of desire: a desire to find itself, know itself, know its limits. And so it does create these projections to understand what it can be. And that’s life summarized as well. And its true that each individual is fragmented, and torn; not because of themselves but by design. The same design that can recognize it as whole too. It’s just you who is unable to recognize this whole. To this, there is this Sanskrit quote that summarizes what you might not have known:

ॐ पूर्णमदः पूर्णमिदं पूर्णात्पूर्णमुदच्यते ।
पूर्णस्य पूर्णमादाय पूर्णमेवावशिष्यते ॥
ॐ शान्तिः शान्तिः शान्तिः ॥

Meaning: This is complete, that is complete. From this whole, that whole arises.
When you take this whole out of that, it’s indeed complete yet again. Peace, Peace, Peace.

This is the idea. You don’t think that is possible because you didn’t assume the nature of this primordial whole which is uncaused. Just by being uncaused, its not graspable by logic. We understand linearity and causality pretty easily. You already know how brain fuck time travel movies can be. Think of it like that.
Think about the first thing that existed and how. Contemplate, introspect, and study at the same time. Whatever answer there is, it will find you.

So, coming to this, we who live our lives in misery, are these torn pages. This is not me saying it. This is Buddha saying “Life is misery”. And to why, everyone says its because you live too tight with your ego. Anything and everything hurts you. Your intuition, your emotions are bulldozered by someone else all the time. That’s why it is indeed miserable in general.

तिनै जलेका पानाहरु
धुँवा बनी उडेको छ
संसार जस्तो भएपनि
अदृश्यतामा रमेकोछ ।

Yes, the smell of misery is everywhere. The burnt smell is flowing here and there. We are all emitting that smell, and its almost as if it has engulfed the whole atmosphere. And where is the fragrance? The fragrance is hiding itself in the safest position away from the burnt smell: as fire that burns it. The smell of burning comes because you know there is somewhere fire that is burning. And that fire is your inner recognition: your inner peace lying within you. The smell that’s reaching your nose is telling you to look for that inner fire which has hidden itself but the symptom of that fire is that smell of burning itself.

हिमालका ती कोप्चारामा
हिउँसँगै जमेकोछ ।।

Yes, its frozen right there. Its not moving. Its still hiding behind that stiffness in all of us.

सुरको धुनमा बज्दा यसलाई
शब्दकोशमा खोजेपछि
आफुलाई नचाहरि
धर्मग्रन्थ रटेपछि
न्यायका ती किताबले नै
सत्यतालाई ढाकेपछि ।

This is one of these things one would say out of anger too. Beautiful words, but I didn’t know anything at that time. It just was written through my being. Neither did I know scriptures, nor did I know where the music was.

Its heavily true that you try to find words to expressions that you cannot understand. Like the origin of universe, there are things which logic can’t hold much longer, but your being knows exactly what its talking about.

If we both have experienced Love, we both understand a lover looking at the moon and appreciating the moon as their lovers. Or them looking at lover’s eyes and comparing it to the moon. We both didn’t communicate in words. We communicated in that imperfect expression of love which is pointing to the feeling that we understood in ourselves.

That is the same with inner Truth. It can’t be expressed in all these words I say. Even Rabindranath Tagore was not able to do it in Gitanjali. But when I read him, I see the same fragrance. Being which has touched the source at least, and wants to get engrossed in it.

In today’s world, not enough people are reading scriptures, yet claiming facts by taking one line/page, and making judgements about it. The wise ones have found Truth in all of them, because the Truth is right there in all of us.

How can it not be in one of the best expressions of us? If you don’t have time to study, better stay away from it. If you want to comment, better study. Just imagine a 12 year old coming at Scientific Literature with 8th grader knowledge. A lot of things in his book were written to simplify it for that 12 year old, but that doesn’t mean its not true, or its not representing Truth.

This is not me saying I know it, but this is the pattern that I have unraveled within these books. I have recognized a few lines, and these are enough pointers for a bigger mystery.
Science is one of the best portals to Truth. If you want to negate religion and scriptures, accept Science as the only Truth. It will take you to your being faster than almost all of those who follow religion.

But, if you already are a skeptic, find your own boxes to put reasoning and your spirituality into. Find contradictions. Don’t open these boxes when you need them just to win arguments. Soon enough, they will start talking to you. You need to give ideas time to settle.

Law, order, society, rituals, traditions, ideas etc. There is bit of truth in all of that but someone will disagree to it all the time. Its an attempt to localize answer for easing our lives. So, understand most of it as that.

Just focus on finding something that is not localized; something that doesn’t change if I put you in Nepal or US or Japan. That will be a good pointer for finding ideas that are universal. That is one good anchor to walk the walk.

सत्य आज मरिसक्यो
जीवनलाई छाडेपछि
मृत्यु सत्य बनिसक्यो
सत्य खोज्न थालेपछि ।।

Haha, this is one of the funniest things about life. There is one simple truth that I can tell you as well. “To this day, everybody who has lived, has died, sooner or later.” Death is simply washing away of all there is. But even Buddha believed in reincarnation.
Finding escape in death is easy, but only if it sure could be an escape. Life is meant to be lived with such vigor and ecstasy knowing its going to come to an end eventually.
Buddhist monks draw a Mandala out of sand, putting in all the effort for weeks for it to look flawless, only to wipe it off after completing it. That is not silly. That is a practice that gets closer to life than anything else. Just because we know that its going to extinguish doesn’t mean we are stopped from creating beauty. We can create beauty with an understanding that it will perish.

When we create beauty with that idea, beauty stands by itself: glorious.
And the way to live life is like that beauty. Those who live like that smell like Truth more than all those who are seeking it. Contradiction all the way, baby.

गढिमाईको मन्दीरमा
मृत्यु नै त सत्य बन्यो
न्याय बन्यो धर्म बन्यो
सत्य सँधै एक्लो बन्यो ।

This will be my controversial take on this after studying this for some time. This is a thin moral line but I don’t mind walking it.
As long as you eat meat, its better if you eat it as offering to some force rather than eating it as is like an animal. Because that helps you understand and lower your ego better. At least, you are recognizing something bigger than you. Making it a festive in hopes to appease Goddess, not so much. FYI: Its not for the main deity that you think the sacrifice is for. Unless there is purity in your heart, much of it is a waste anyway.

And for those who realize, they don’t even have to do a Sattvic Yajna or a ritual offering flowers. There is only one true offering: offering of your ego (false identity).

For those who realize, there is no difference between eating meat/ not eating meat. I don’t want to expound or teach anything. If you have a Guru, do what he tells you to do. If you don’t, guide it with your own moral compass.

You become more sensitive when you don’t eat. It eases your meditation as well. Stopping just at this.

कतै मुस्कान लहरसँगै
कतै रगत खोलो बग्यो
आलो रगत चरुसँगै
सत्य यज्ञ भष्म बन्यो ।

Death is one simple truth that we all know. The reason why they put Tika of “Bhasma** on their forehead in some traditions of Hinduism relates to this idea beautifully. You need to adore death as your personal friend. There are so many sects in Hinduism and Buddhism that meditate on the cremation ground. Death is but natural for them. Those who see it see everything as indifferent from one another.

Yes, truth is in that “Bhasma**. I didn’t know it at the time. I know it now. And its much pure than the best of temples you visit where people pretend to be, but have no true compassion.

All ideas of morality are fake if you don’t have an internal moral compass.

त्यै भष्मको कालो टीका
धर्मको त प्रतिक बन्यो
सत्य अब जलिसक्यो
यो माटोलाई त्यागिसक्यो
विनाशतिर लम्काएर
संसारदेखि भागिसक्यो ।।

Yes, this is the world we live in. Find those who don’t pretend, who are raw. They might hurt you, they might pain you, but they will eventually lead you to truth. You shouldn’t put on for anyone for it hides your being a little. Little by little, you forget who you are. You will be despised, desolate for doing so, but that’s the path of Truth.

Truth is personal. You cannot show it to someone who has closed their eyes by their own will.

Just look at how Premanand Maharaj talks about his Bhakti. That is a smell most people can understand.

So, this is my conclusion. I have traveled far and wide within myself and the world to realize what I do today. I am raw here because you know that you can be, at least with yourself personally. It is the best weapon to tear through all illusions.

A decade ago, I felt desolate, alone in my room. No idea where I was going, yet with almost everything that the world usually fights for. I had most of these things they wished, but it was only baggage for me. I didn’t know who I was. The only time I felt home was when I was below the night sky, watching those stars. They made me feel like they were watching me, protecting me. I felt alone among all the people who knew me. And in that desolate moment, I couldn’t see any light of truth anywhere. That’s why I wrote that last verse.

But today, I know that its almost everywhere for those who have the earnest eyes.

For those who don’t lie, even to themselves.

For those who are sensitive enough to look for it even in the remotest of places. There are stories of Sufi saints living as Butchers, so open your eyes to the possibility.

Don’t lie to yourself, even as self-deprecating humor.

What you don’t know, don’t assume. Ask if you have to. Write your things down.

Be patient with answers. Some questions take years to get answered, some might get answered by next person you meet.

Always be listening heartily, not to answer, listen to listen.

Anchor yourselves in Truth and Truth alone. Sooner or later, you will find that what you are looking for.

Be empathetic, be brave.

Truth is not for cowards.

There is a reason why they used emblem of Lotus flower. If you don’t have courage to get yourselves dirty, you have no point asking for that Lotus.

When you have that fragrance, the world will be a little bit more beautiful.

So, Bloom amidst the mud surrounding you !!

item.title: Smiling like a madman
item.description:
First I was innocent,
I asked for an identity,
The world pushed me down and pained me.
I talked to the world about this pain,
And the world mocked me.


I felt alone in this fight,
I wanted to run away.
But, she didn't let me.
She made me break into a thousand pieces,
But always took great care that none was lost.
And when I gave up,
She made me work on myself.
And That's how I recollected myself to be wholler than the whole.


-------------------------------xx-------------------------------


Second I was in limelight,
I asked for strength,
Then the eyes of the world fixated at me pained me.
Their dreams, their expectations,
Them trying to fulfill their dreams through me.
I again talked to the world about the burden of expectations,
And the world really didn't care.

I felt alone again in this fight,
I wanted to run away.
But, she didn't let me.
She made me take even more burden until I broke again,
Yet she took great care again that none was lost.
And when I gave up,
She made me work on myself.
And That's how I recollected myself to be wholler than the whole again.


-------------------------------xx-------------------------------


Third, I was now strong enough to take any burden.
I asked for truth,
I started wandering here and there in search of truth,
The words from thousand masters buzzed like a bomb inside my head.
But by now, I knew the world never listened.
So I chose a few I was hoping would listen without judgement,
Tried telling them about the never ending search,
Yet they too didn’t get much.

I was feeling utterly alone by then,
I wanted to run away.
But, she didn't let me.
I had to sit there with thousand petals opening inside me,
Yet not even an eye to appreciate.
I wanted to help those few to make it bloom in them,
Yet each one had their own doubts.


The petals bloomed,
The petals faded,
And they fell back to the ground.
Forgetting the fact that it is the nature of petals to fall off,
I started crying seeing all those petals within withering away,
Yet she took great care to collect them all for me.
And when I gave up crying,
She held my hand,
She reached out to me with the incense she prepared from those flowers,
And That’s how I recollected myself to be wholler than the whole again.



-------------------------------xx-------------------------------


Fourth, I realized myself and my relationship with her.
Through her eyes,
I realized the world too was her all along.
Now, I was no longer bashing my head,
Neither was I trying to make the world understand me.
I was happy with the fragrance she left me with.


One day, I realized she had been with me the whole time,
And then, I no longer needed to run away.
I no longer needed to say anything to the world,
Or hear back something from there.
I no longer was bashing my head.
I was just there lost in the fragrance of the flowers,
And she came.
She asked me to not get lost in that fragrance,
And gave me keys to her garden itself.


Now, I sit there smiling like a madman. ☺️

item.content:
The Dream of Liberation: From Fear to Truth

The wise ones teach that the universe was born from the desire of The One—not out of pity, not to cause pain, but from a longing to multiply and know itself.

As the Chhandogya Upanishad (6.2.1) declares,

“sadeva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyam

taddhaika āhurasadevedamagra

āsīdekamevādvitīyaṃ tasmādasataḥ sajjāyata”

—“Somya, before this world was manifest there was only existence, one without a second. On this subject, some maintain that before this world was manifest there was only non-existence, one without a second. Out of that non-existence, existence emerged.”

Similarly, the Aitareya Upanishad (1.1.1) states,

“om atma va idameka evagra asit nanyat kincana misat sa iksata lokannu srija iti ”

—“OM ! In the beginning this was but the absolute Self alone . There was nothing else whatsoever that winked . It thought , " Let Me create the worlds ." ”

Again, Brihadharanyak Upanishad (1.4.2) says,

“Sa va na iva reme,tasmād ekākī na ramate;

sa dvitīya ma icchat”

—“The One didn’t enjoy being solitary. Therefore, the one desired to be two.

From this primal desire, consciousness split, and the universe exploded into multiplicity. But with this division came pain and suffering, born from the loss of divinity. No longer The One, we became bottles of consciousness—confused, searching, unaware of our origin or destination. What was meant to be a game of enjoyment isn’t enjoyment anymore. Yet, as the sages remind us, it’s alright to be confused. The journey back to truth begins with patience. Shakti upasaks and Sufi saints are the prime examples of who can enjoy this duality like no one else. If you understand its a game you chose to play, then it can be fun and exciting for you. But that’s a whole another story for another day. Lets just focus on “Dream of Liberation” for now.

And in that same Brihadaranyak Upanishad, (1.4.1) there is this quote just above this one that goes like this:

sa abibhet

tasmād ekākī bibheti;

sa ha ayam īkṣāṃ cakre,

yat mad anyan nāsti,

kaṣma annu bibhema īti,

tata evāsya bhayaṃ vīyāya,

kasma addhyabheṣyat

dvitīyādvai bhayaṃ bhavati

which means

“It was alone and became fearful. Reflecting, it thought, ‘Since there is nothing else but me, what is there to fear?’ Thus, its fear vanished. For fear arises only from the presence of another.”

I hope this clarifies fear, desire and truth as said by the wise ones.

I’ve never met a Himalayan Yogi my entire life. Yet, their idea reached me through multiple books and biographies of such saints. Their vision, I believe, is Spiritual Liberation —a return to unity, to the unconditioned state of being. But there’s a closer dream, a stepping stone: liberation from fear. I’d read it somewhere that’s their immediate dream. So, I am here to contribute to that dream. This is where my story begins, and where I hope to make a difference.

Buddha’s Truth: Life is Suffering

Lets understand fear and suffering with another lens. A lens that’s so sharp and astute. None other than Buddha and his teachings.

When the Buddha attained enlightenment, his first words captured the essence of existence:

“Anekajāti samsāram, Sandhāvissam anibbisam, Gahakārakam gavesanto, Dukkhā jāti punappunam”—“Through many a birth in samsara, have I wandered in vain, seeking the builder of this house of life. Repeated birth is indeed suffering.”

He saw the house-builder—the cycle of craving—and declared,

“Gahakāraka dittho si, Puna gehaṁ na kāhasi”—“O house-builder, you are seen. You will not build this house again.”

His mind reached the unconditioned, free from desire.

Buddha, a Himalayan Yogi in spirit, revealed the Four Noble Truths, the first being: Life is suffering. Through paths like Hinayana, Mahayana, and Vajrayana, he offered ways to transcend this suffering. Today, Tibetan monks in the Himalayan foothills practice his teachings, meditating in dark caves for years, seeking liberation.

Upon first glance, Buddha’s view seems to contradict the idea of desire. But if you have studied Buddhism in little more depth, then you know what created the house in the first place. And that Buddha is indeed talking about “Desire” that was building the house again and again. Like the wise quote, “Truth is One but the explanations are many.”

From them, we inherited tools like meditation and yoga—ancient practices, nearly 2,000 years old, designed not to ease our worldly stress but to cut through the illusion of existence and attain nirvana, enlightenment, unity.

Yet, modern practitioners often misunderstand these tools. Yoga’s Eightfold Path—Yama, Niyama, Asana, Pranayama, Pratyahara, Dharana, Dhyana, and Samadhi—is rarely followed in its entirety. Even yoga teachers struggle to grasp its depth. Meditation, too, is often reduced to a quick fix for daily stress, far from its original purpose. This realization drove me to create something new, rooted in the wisdom of the past but tailored to our present needs. I’m no teacher, but as a keen student, I’ve looked deeper than most. Through eight years of meditation, study of Hinduism, Buddhism, stories of Sufi saints, and even Egyptian history, I’ve glimpsed the essence of the Yogis’ dream.

My Journey: The Truth That Transforms

My transformation began with Vipassana, the meditation technique taught by the Buddha. I had read many scriptures, but I had zero experience of truth.

Two 10-day silent retreats revealed truths that had been invisible, lurking right before my eyes. Then, in a single moment, reality struck me with undeniable force, like lightning, shattering my illusions.

Years later, I realized it wasn’t the silence or the process that transformed me — it was the truth staring me down, impossible to ignore. I fought so hard that when it broke me, the light entered.

Words from scriptures and wise ones became more clearer as I continued meditating.

I’ve seen others attend Vipassana retreats, some even 20 times, yet miss the fundamental lesson. I’ve met those who can quote scriptures fluently but never grasp their essence. My fortune lies in recognizing what truly changed me: not a technique, but the raw encounter with my personal truth. And I want that to happen with you too.

The Vision: An App to Face Fear

This insight inspired me to create an app—not for liberation or enlightenment, but for a more immediate goal: to help you face your undeniable truth and liberate yourself from fear. Fear binds us, just as it bound our cave-dwelling ancestors. Despite humanity’s progress—our trust in one another, our interconnected lives sustained by thousands across the globe—we still fear the world. We eat food we don’t grow, wear clothes we don’t make, yet tremble with the same primal anxieties.

This app is a tool to clean your mirror, to reflect your truth clearly. It’s meant to be used and then discarded, like a ladder climbed and left behind. It won’t grant spiritual liberation, but it will take you to the first step: a world where fear no longer drives you. Generations have survived wars, brutality, and chaos, yet we’ve grown together, trusted, and thrived. This app will remind you of that resilience, showing you a world there’s not much to fear. Most of your anxieties comes from your caveman survival instinct deeply coded onto your genes.

Unlocking Infinite Potential

You sit atop infinite potential, bound only by fear. My mission is to help you unlock it. This journey may take years, even decades, but with true effort, you’ll be able to find your personal truth. You will finally live like royalty—free to meditate, to create, to arrive at the world awaiting you. Until your mirror is clean, you cannot comprehend what lies ahead.

The Himalayan Yogis dreamed of spiritual liberation, but their closer dream—freedom from fear—is within our reach. This app is my offering to that vision, a bridge to a fearless world. Let’s eliminate fear first. Then, together, we’ll see what comes next.

I had the idea almost two years ago. I am sorry for taking this long to build this. Finally as AI got better, it helped my development path quiet a lot. This is not a sales pitch because I don’t expect anything from you except that you someday arrive at that place where I arrived some years ago.

No data collection, no ads, no money to pay.

Locked to only you so that you can record deepest darkest thoughts without worrying a bit. Just use it so that one day you can throw it away. I might add feature to share your stories to one another for moral boost someday. Until then, its not even connecting to the internet.

Only thing that it requires is your attention to your life: observing the patterns of your mind until you’re free from it.

This is my personal motivation and my dream behind creating this project.

More tools will come at https://maitreyatools.com.

item.title: 2024 in a nutshell
item.description:

2023 was speeding with insights. Its been a slow year compared to 2023 because everything was about calming down. We built a home for ourselves. I realized having a home that you design and build yourself based on how you want it to look like and make you feel, is a great blessing. Its been one wholesome journey to build my home.

I started this year differently compared to years before. In the year’s end, I saw who I could become, who I was and got some glimpse into what 2024 was going to be about. Really got energized already at the start.

2023 was speeding with insights. Its been a slow year compared to 2023 because everything was about calming down. We built a home for ourselves. I realized having a home that you design and build yourself based on how you want it to look like and make you feel, is a great blessing. Its been one wholesome journey to build my home.

Completed watching One Piece this year. The theme, the friendship, the adventure all really engulfed me to feel like I am one of them. Such a joy. This year I watched two more animes: Jujitsu Kaizen ( Fight scenes were animated so good that I enjoyed fight scenes for the very first time in movies/animes ), and Demon Slayer ( Enjoyed watching it but nothing very specific to say about it).

In the process, one instance where I over-analyzed One Piece awakening to enlightenment and creation:

One question I had for a long time was whether I wanted enlightenment or creation. That answer came today. Enlightenment is like having infinite observation haki as well as zoan type devil fruit that has will of it’s own. Once its awakened, its will is yours and yours is its will. So, the way I am going to balance is similar to how devil fruits awakening gets balanced. You don’t always awaken it but only when needed. That way you can have it your way. – 2024-02-17

Who knows, maybe I will have my way. Its a contradiction in itself and nothing really comes out of pondering on it. If it happens, I will know. Until it happens, its a play of my mind. Taking rest right there. 😁

Next thing I got this year is understanding of role of Divine Feminine in all of creation and enlightenment. It was always clear to me about the creative aspect of it but I hadn’t gone very deep into it. The more I have learned of divine feminine and her presence in my life, I have been more clear and clear about what I need. I realized I was getting everything I need without even asking for it. Its happening step by step weirdly, and I am excited to see on which note 2025 ends in.

While saying this, its really essential to understand the difference between not acting at all vs acting without tying yourself to the fruits of it. I have always wanted to be autotelic and in that process, there is no place for thought about outcome while at it. I enjoy it, and that’s the outcome. I do plan, I do act accordingly. I use my cognitive ability to come up with improved solutions, but I don’t tie myself to any act or its output. This is the basics of “Karma Yog” of Bhagvad Geeta. You will always know what you need to do and do it. If you know you aren’t doing something to avoid boredom, that’s enough information to know. Rest will fall in place.

There have been pointers that have blown my mind this year. I don’t know if they are real or not, but I know if they are real, they demand my 100 percent on it. 2025 will be about verifying those pointers as well. It will end in either of two ways I will live my life. I have one of these two ways to live my life:

  1. Live a life of a monk. Accepting everything as is and not really owning anything. Knowing its all ephemeral and will end.
  2. Live a life of a king. Knowing that everything is yours but if everything is yours, there is nothing that you need to possess because its already yours.

A drawing of what creation/enlightenment seems to be explained like:

2025 will decide what life I am going to live. Therefore for 2025, I have set my theme color as purple/violet ( the color of the sahasrara ) 🟣🔮🟪 .

This year, for the first time in my life, I visited museums and art galleries. I used to read about art, renaissance, history but never put in time to just enjoy these in real life. I moved from one place to another multiple times finally ending my stay in the valley temporarily after 11 years, starting a new phase.

I always try to read a decent number of books. I don’t decide which books I read. I put a lot of books on my boox device and just let the mood decide which I read/complete. Timing chooses books. Some get completed, some don’t. Sometimes I just reading 20% of a book and move to the next. Sometimes, I come back to it again and again, only to read few pages and move to the next. But overall, reading has been one of my favorite pastimes. A big credit of who I am today is to the books that have found me. Hope amazing books find you too in 2025.

Books re-read

  • The Creative Act : A way of Being by Rick Rubin ( This book is such a masterpiece of creating art. I think it will be valuable as people will try to find identity in a world where AI will start doing most of the tasks that we have been doing. )
  • Facebook’s Little Red Book ( This is such a clear book of theme, vision and why values matter. Inspiration always wins. Each page is a beauty. I need a physical copy now. )

Completed This year

  • Breath: The New Science of a Lost Art ( The activity that we do the most frequent in our lives needed to be at least understood. Though I haven’t deeply pursued each findings present in the book, I understand not to breath via mouth except for relaxation. And I agree that increasing VO2 max (a.k.a. lung capacity) is a good indicator for overall longevity. )
  • The Root Stanzas of the Middle Way: The Mulamadhyamkarika by Nagarjuna ( This is a masterpiece of Mahayana Tradition of Buddhism. It took some time to go into details and understand it but the philosophical treatise is something that will keep me pondering over and over. Really good guide on what exactly is emptiness. Its contradictions seem ironical, but if you have experienced something along the way, it fits right in the middle like the title suggests. )
  • Pride and Prejudice ( First fiction I read this year. Its always refreshing to read books that have happy ending. LOL 🤭 One thing I have realized is human emotions have always remained the same throughout time. Feels like just the clothes and environment has changed. Like you can play same game with different background. Made me realize how unique we think of ourselves but in the end the emotional body is very close to many who have already lived and died. )
  • The Picture of Dorian Gray ( Such a beautiful book. Such good philosophy sprinkled over like salt over good food. Title having name Gray suits it. Grayness of morality clarified in a intricate manner)
  • The Importance of Being Earnest ( A humorous read )
  • Living with the Himalayan Masters by Swami Rama ( Swami Rama is a sage who taught many breathing techniques to the west and also tried doing experiments to show what he can do by controlling breathing like controlling heart rate, temperature etc. but much of that remains to debate now. Got to know him from book on Breath. )
  • Love Whispers ( After reading Swami Rama’s autobiography, wanted to learn more about him. This is collection of excerpts from his diary where he shares his intimate relationship with Divine Feminine.)
  • Atmamun by Kapil Gupta ( Live life like a monk or like a king. Find your way and live it. This has helped me corroborate what I had felt like as to how to live my life. I know how much I can know, how much I need to know, and not be troubled by what I don’t know or wouldn’t know in this lifetime. So, I am going to live. )
  • The Joy of Abstraction by Eugenia Cheng ( Completed this to get a good enough understanding of category theory because Bartosz’s Category Theory book wasn’t clearing all my doubts. She had a good video about it, so I read it. Book is good for a basic understanding. )

In Progress

  • I am That by Nisargadatta Maharaj ( Clarifies a lot of philosophical discussions around enlightenment and being in general, half way through )
  • Category Theory for Programmers by Bartosz ( Completed the basic chapters, now on to intermediate )
  • Essential Rumi ( Getting to know his life and poems, this man is something else if you talk of love )
  • Professor Frisby’s Mostly Adequate Guide to Functional Programming ( Got the basics, practiced some, but haven’t completed it)
  • Catch 22 ( Re-read upto some chapters only to get stalled again, this book doesn’t want to be read for some weird reason 😝 )
  • The Beginning of Infinity ( Close to completing it this time. Such an amazing book. The concepts to which he concludes coming from a whole different perspective is something else. It became a lot like my revisit to Philosophy, Quantum Mechanics, and Optimism. )

Notes

  • Reading about spirituality is one thing, experiencing it is another.
  • Its ironical that people have been forcing meditation. Its something that you have to have discipline about but that discipline should be limited to your body. You cannot tame your mind in the same way you tame your body. Only way out is to watch where the mind goes with sharp-pointedness that the mind sees the futility of its moving. Your mind always knows the tricks you try to play with it and always will outsmart you. Who even is you, if not the mind right now? So, just watch. Don’t care whoever is watching and whoever is being watched. The patterns unravel themselves right before you when you don’t try, when you don’t force to bring something to the surface.
  • I am reading more and more about Himalayan sages, Tantra and knowing more about the enlightened masters.
  • I have been very curious about my heritage, who my ancestors have been, why they did what they did, and if there’s something to be learned about. And I have come across a few things that we have lost through our generations. There are rabbit holes wherever you try to pursue.
  • Category Theory has felt harder to unravel for me but nonetheless beautiful. I have yet to understand the beauty of structure that it provides, but I am hopeful in the process.
  • The progress that has been made on AI seems awesome. I am looking forward to what we will see in our lifetimes with optimism.
  • I predicted a 10 year prediction this year to understand myself as well as the world better. https://x.com/_aloki/status/1847607326036922409

Ending this with the poem from Dylan Thomas:

Do not go gentle into that good night,

Old age should burn and rave at close of day;

Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

item.content:
I have been trying to write some essays on basic words that are the hardest to capture because often times it’s these words that stir up conflict: love, happiness, fulfillment, peace, pain, god, spirituality etc. Because they are the most overused, yet least understood by our subconscious minds, our subconscious gets trippy while making sense. I started writing this essay about six months ago. In trying to write this essay, I started by searching for word love in my personal notes vault. It got overwhelming even after a day digesting, that I gave up the pursuit for some time. I really didn’t have any digest apart from notes and excerpts from others. I knew where to start, but couldn’t end it.

This is where I start. Where is love word used often? Whenever anyone feels like there is an intensity of anything, they call it love. Examples:

  • Desire : Love for ownership
  • Passion : Love for fulfillment
  • Sex : Love for pleasure
  • Flow : Love for work

etc. If love is just intensity at its peak, why is love praised that much? Can you call intense greed as love for greed? If not, why do you call high intensity to cause violence as love for violence. If it can be used on any connotation, is there really anything praiseworthy about it? e.g.

Paulo Coelho in The Alchemist says maybe love simply is nourishment and compares love to a falcon’s flight over the sand being definition of love given by the desert. The desert reasons that falcon carries bits of itself, and feeds the falcon little water that it has right there; thus the nourishment.

Lao Tzu in Tao Te Ching talks about love without imposing the will, love as a leader, love as a mystery, and posits a spiritual question. “Is greatest love indifferent?”

Gabriel Gracia Marquez in One Hundred Years of Solitude shows how you see love everywhere, how passion and love interchangably entangle, whether we can be exhausted of love, and whether two solitary people can be in love. Charles Bukwoski has a book titled “Love is a dog from hell.”

There will be thousand more references to word love if you google it. I deferred this essay and had been trying to answer other questions related to fear and death instead for last year. All of a sudden, both the answers came at the same time. Finally, I had an essay I wanted to share.

I want to make note of what’s easiest about describing love. Love with a person. Though I start with romantic love, the conclusion applies to any love. Love with a person, thing, God, or anything. I will start with loving someone as I have come to know it. I have been close with a few people emotionally. Had multitudes of experience from love at first sight ( in people’s words ) to being in a relationship. I have connected with someone on a purely intellectual level where we had so much topics in common that we talked for hours on end, and never get tired. I have been emotionally involved with someone who matched most of my interests. It was fun to talk to and hangout with that someone. I thought I was at least in love when I was with someone in a relationship, in possessing someone whom I called mine. At that time I thought life was about one love and I believed it to be love for a very long time. Then I liked someone, wanted to be with them, but never really feeling like being with them. At some point, I saw love in trying to emapthize for someone. There were few days where situation would make it feel like a perfect match but that was pleasure misinterpreted as love.

What people call love at first sight was all hormones piling up to give one of the most pleasurable experiences, but not really love. On my first ever love at first sight, I really felt music buzz my ears, stomach curled up when I saw her. I was sure she was an angel that evening. But hormones fade, as fast as they pile up. That’s what love at first sight is. It’s a biological response of you liking someone because nature wants you to breed.

Being intimate emotionally and intellectually with someone is freedom, one degree close to love than even that pleasure where you had a crush. You put down your guards. It’s not overwhelming like the first one, but much more relieving. A crush moment is instantaneous, but intimacy lasts.

Being in a relationship came as a whole different story. They are already as important as your family, and when you have accepted their most vices as inconsequential is even more closer to love than anything else. This is what I thought was love till the moment because that was all that I had experienced. You possess them as yours. You feel safe with them. Most of the feeling comes from not having an emotional void to express with someone when in a relationship.

I thought that was all there is. Thus, I believed the highest attainment is love where two people are in a relationship, like each other, and spend their lives together. They are individuals, but they like spending their life together rather than all alone.

Then came my final experience, which needed me to redefine what I had known so far. This is love where I experienced this wierdness that I had a difficult time finding words to describe.

Lets start with a context first.

I had crush on someone for some time. I got to talking with that someone, meeting them too. At that time, I was trying to see as many people as I can, in a hope to understand my preferences better. That someone didn’t want to take it forward, so I left that situation the best I can. I was dating other people, but very briefly. I got stuck on that someone emotionally.

I was still unsure whether I wanted to be with them because I couldn’t take this in a normal pace. I was already thinking long term without knowing them enough. And making decisions quickly on emotional matters is not my forte. I tried hard to move away from them, dated a few other people, but still stuck.

I had one doubt about that person being the right match, that’s why I never went all in. One day while reading a book, I came to an understanding that opened that barrier for me. It had been an year or so since I had last talked. I decided to take a chance and take it as it goes even if it ends up hurting me. I called to meet and that someone agreed.

First I was happy, then I was anxious. I almost had forgotten how anxiety felt like because I was experiencing any sort of anxiety after almost a year. To give you context, I have been meditating for years now, and am rarely anxious. That day, I couldn’t sleep and decided to meditate.

Meditation is where my inner lake gets calm. Half an hour into that, I realized anxiety arises from desire, not from love. I still meditated. There is a practice called “Metta” ( Good will and Gratitude Practice ) that’s done at the end of Vipassana meditation practice. It usually is done for the last five minutes, but I decided to do it amidst my one hour practice that day. Also, I decided to do Metta just for that someone. In that practice of radiating love, after 10 minutes or so, my desire slowly faded away. Voila!! There was no anxiety.

I was peaceful, full of love, and cheerful. It felt so fucking weird that I couldn’t make sense of it. It didn’t last very long, about an hour or so after I woke from meditation. But at that moment, I felt blissed like I had never been before. The weiredest part is that I was unafraid of even death. It felt like even if someone stabbed me in that moment, I would die peacefully with a smile on my face. There was one more catch to it: I had always heard about how ego is the final barrier in spiritual path, to which I realized I had no ego that whole time. Not even a tinge of it. I was ready to give anything and everything up cheerfully.

I had been reading and meditating on death and fear for almost an year now in trying to overcome it. I had built a decent enough understanding about the topics, but not really nailed it. I was still seeking for an answer. I had no idea that my answer would come this way.

Even when that someone decided lastly that they didn’t want to meet me, there was pain. But I didn’t want that pain to subside. I remained aware and calm through it. I wanted to feel everything in its fullest depth. My logical mind couldn’t make sense because that was not how people I saw dealt with heartbreak neither in real life nor in movies. I wanted to just feel everything without diverting it by movies, songs, drinking, or activity of any sort. Seeing this, my mind created a doubt as to whether I really was in love or I was just faking myself. Only because that experience was way too vivid and absorbing, denying that didn’t come easy.

Days passed and I still couldn’t believe what happened. Over a period of a month, I came across some references that described what I felt. I stumbled across couple more references, and then I finally found my answer as to what happened.

First is a story told by Osho: One day desire and knowledge met with Ganga. Ganga told both of them that she would purify them. Knowledge didn’t go but desire did. When desired came purified out of the river, it’d became love.

I found few Rumi’s quotes:

  • From understading comes love.
  • Exhale only love.
  • Close your eyes, fall in love, stay there.
  • You have within you more love than you could ever understand.
  • Your task is not to seek for love, but merely to seek and find all the barriers within yourself that you have built against it.

This guy was in love like no one else. I felt connection to these lines immediately after seeing one. It would have been impossible for me to express it, had it not been this guy who had said it already. My experience would have been lost to my logic and memory had I not found his lines.

Finally, it does not like a hallucination or a dream I created. Though that state lasted only an hour or so, that was real. That was how Rumi loved The Godhead. That’s what love as in love is. Everything else is love added with something: sometimes with desire, sometimes with pleasure, sometimes with work, sometimes with passion etc.

Experiences and insights from meditation rarely last long. It takes one moment to see the door, but years more to absorb it into day-to-day life. I am grateful that I got a rare glimpse.

This is my essay “On Love”.

item.description:
Books read this year

  • Brave New World
  • One Hundred Years of Solitude
  • The Twilight Saga [ 1-4 ]
  • How to Read a Book
  • What would you do if you weren’t afraid?
  • Turiya - The God State: Beyond Kundalini, Kriya Yoga & all Spirituality (Real Yoga)
  • How Psychology Works
  • Being You: A New Science of Consciousness
  • How to find love
  • Make something wonderful
  • American Gods
  • The Tibetan Book of Living and Dying
  • Logicomix
  • The Phoenix Project
  • The Art of Dying by Osho
  • The Old Man and the sea
  • Zen Mind Beginners Mind
  • Isa Upanishad
  • Chhandogya Upanishad
  • Enlightenment is your nature
  • 101 Essays That Will Change the Way You Think

Books In Progress:

Remnants from Last Year

  • Dhando Investor [ Not in that mental state of value investing rn ]
  • Lives of the Stoics [ Got enough philosophy to be useful ]
  • Meditations by Marcus Aurelius [ Same with meditations ]
  • Code Breaker by Walter Issacson [ Excited upto the point of decision for a Nobel Prize. Felt like that was all I needed ]
  • Krishnamurti’s Notebooks [ Needs absorption rather than completion ]
  • Dream Yourself Awake [ Practice is more important. Only after mastering certain techniques, I will move forward ]
  • The Monk who sold his Ferrari [ Started re-reading but dropped it ]

Newly added

  • Love Her Wild
  • The Sun and her flowers
  • Milk and Honey
  • Zen and The Art of Motorcycle Maintenance [ Too much zen already :P ]
  • Indian Philosophy [ It’s a big one. So much information, it’s hard to just process ]
  • The Book of Secrets by Osho [ About techniques, no point in finishing the book ]
  • Mulamadhyamkarika: Wisdom of the Middle Way by Nagarjuna [ Really intrigued by first chapter but cannot get time to contemplate on the ideas, pretty complex ]
  • Oxford Handbook on Philosophy of Death [ Philosophy needs decent time to digest through introspection and speculation, which I currently don’t have ]
  • Head First Design Patterns
  • The Little Book about OS Development
  • The God Delusion
  • Godel Escher Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid [ Really beautiful ideas which I really want to absorb, rather than read ]
  • Salt, Fat, Acid, Heat: A Science of Cooking
  • The Beginning of Infinity
  • The Design of Everyday Things
  • Lokpriya Sayar aur Unki Sayari
  • Catch 22

Notes

  • I read word “Bardo” for the first time in Godel Escher Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid. When I read The Tibetan Book of Dying and Living, I found out that Bardo was a Tibetan word taken into English, and has a very big significance in Tibetan.
  • Tibetans are very clear about stages after death, re-incarnation, enlightenment on par with our clarity about daily tasks we do.
  • The more I read about neuroscience, the more I love reading philosophy.
  • On Sanskrit and Sanskrit Texts:
    • Sanskrit Grammar is such an elegant topic that was written a long time ago. I have no problem with people rejecting anything, but if we have no appreciation for the roots that we gave to the world, we are losing our identity into it. Sanskrit Grammar is one of the first complete grammar of any language in the world. Very elaborate.
    • I am more intrigued by Eastern Philosophy because it’s easy to understand, easy because it fills gaps from our traditions, other related stories like Puranas, and folklores. Since Nepali language is derived from Sanskrit as well, I can contemplate some ideas from Sanskrit into my mind directly too. I have at least learned primitive level Sanskrit Grammar.
    • Most of the Buddhist texts were originally written in Sanskrit and Pali. Still to this day, Tibetans read both Sanskrit and Tibetan translation.
    • In Nepal and India, we see Hinduism as this giant ball of tradition. We, as intellectuals, need to be able to separate contemporary usefulness of traditions from philosophy, and give it a fair chance without making it a mockery by comparing it with Western Philosophy.
    • Upanishads are the lesser known beautiful extracts of Hindu tradition that comes under Vedanta. Upanishads are called Vedanta [ The End of Vedas ] because it’s said that they contain all the teachings of Veda in a more succinct form. Philosophical foods of thought that have been neglected because it’s hard to make philosophy a part of tradition unlike stories ( a.k.a Puranas ). There are many Upanishads, but 108 principal ones. Among them, 9 or 11 are said to be of significant importance. They are just like a few poems long.
  • Make Something Wonderful by Steve Jobs is a simple yet beautiful book on how Steve’s mind worked. And, it really is inspiring for someone who wants to build stuff for people.
  • Every school should teach How to Read a Book. Reading is not just memorizing or marking something as complete. Reading is much more. And it depends on what you are reading. You shouldn’t read everything the same way. Like Francis Bacon said, “Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested.” It’s easier said than done.
  • Having a kindle really helps me because I can pick and drop books at any time without feeling guilty about it. I usually have around 200 books on my kindle.
  • If you are curious about getting overview and some details into theory of consciousness, Being You by Anil Seth is a great book. I loved his talks through the years, and this is a good digest of the whole field of consciousness and his theory of it.
  • Read Psychology so you can understand your mind better. Reading Psychology + Meditating helps me clarify a lot of my confusions, and helps me accept conclusions that I don’t feel like accepting.
  • I have been pretty intrigued by death for a year or two now because I see it as hindrance to my true fulfillment. How can I truly be if I am always running away from something invisible? I still have amends to make, but a lot of ideas have been still like a lake on my mind. It’s not that the waves don’t come, but they settle quickly. I hope to be in equanimity with death soon enough, so that I can truly live.
  • Zen is nothing more nothing less than mindfulness. There can be a thousand teachings and koans, but the essence is to simply be. The closest example of Zen that you can understand is Kung Fu Panda. Compare Master Shifu, Po, and Master Oogway; right in that comparison is answer to what Zen is. Knowing is one thing; accepting is another which you can learn from Shifu.
  • I am really loving Godel Escher Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid.

If you have any recommendations, or want certain recommendations; hit me up.

item.content:
We all identify our bodies as “my body” and not me directly. The whole idea of this blog post revolves around this idea. The purpose of this blog post is to establish an idea on how to build healthier lifestyle based on this concept.

It’s not like we intentionally don’t want to build healthier habits. We try to pick up exercise habits, but we are too lazy to work on it. We eat haphazardly, and without any consideration to our health. It’s a very universal problem. So, I had the same problem. On top of that, I have always been a person low in Conscientiousness, which means I used to have a hard time pushing my goals to myself if I was the only one responsible for it. Finally, I found a way that worked for me that might work for you too.

So, the main idea is this: Instead of thinking of my body as me (same identity), I changed the scenario by treating “my body” as being separate from “me”. Now, There are two players in the game. Player 1 : Me[ My emotions, cravings, feelings ] Player 2 : My body [ Physical body ] Both of whom are playing an optimization game to favor themselves.

My body communicates via muscle signals, dis-ease, etc. My thoughts are self-evident.

For me, the game started looking like a zero-sum optimization game at the beginning. e.g. Either I was taking care of my health or I was fulfilling my cravings, and feel-good emotions. But as I came to understand intentions of both players [ my body and me ] with more clarity, the same game resurfaced as a positive-sum game. This change of the game itself happened as my perspective on what I was optimizing for aligned with what my body wanted to optimize. In simpler terms, I’d thought building healthy habits would be boring which turned out to be a false proposition.

I started by clarifying the goals of each player in this optimization game. Each goal has time to feedback as well as importance of feedback. Based on a weighted sum of feedback, based on time as well as importance, the decision’s made. Initially, the goals and their characteristics looked as follows:

Goal for agent 1 ( me )

  1. Tastes good : Immediate feedback, High importance to feedback.
  2. Feels good ( e.g. Drinking alcohol in other’s company though it doesn’t taste good ): Immediate feedback, High importance to feedback.
  3. Avoid any physical pain : No immediate feedback since punishment’s delayed in time. Low importance to feedback. ( e.g. I don’t immediately get obese. )

Goal for agent 2 ( my body )

  1. Not be obese : Very long feedback time
  2. Not have bowel difficulties : Medium feedback time
  3. No soar muscles : Medium feedback time

OVERALL GOAL : Lesser conflicts between body and mind.

NOTE: From now on, I might refer to me as player 1 and my body as player 2.

So, this optimization game is biased more towards me feeling good than my body feeling good because the feedback loops associated to the game have easy short-time feedback circuits that favor Player 1. So, it’s obvious that the game’s results favor me feeling good in the short term rather than both me and my body feeling good in a longer term. So, I needed a way to overcome that.

The optimization game’s thus defined. The players in the game are defined. The goals associated with the players are defined. The weight of each action for these players in relation to the goal is defined.

To maximize my overall goal, I thus needed to find a way to make Player 2’s goals being equally considered as Player 1’s are. I had to change weights on the game in some way that it doesn’t discount short-term rewards favoring Player 1 over Player 2’s fulfillment.

If I can do this, this changes the situation for Player 2 in the game so both players have an equal say for actions that affect them both.

This is how I increased Player 2’s impact in the optimization game. I defined my relationship to my body like a “close friend”. What that means is that I’ll have to maintain basic requisites for being my body’s friend. I cannot just abuse it right away, and expect it to maintain a good relationship with me. I cannot be absolutely naive with my best friend, but we can be a bit abusive to each other every now and then. By hitting rough edges and coming together, our friendships get stronger. I treat my body in a similar fashion now.

Let’s talk about this with some examples:

  1. I want to drink, but I won’t go drinking one day after another just to feel good. I will restrain my taste to let my body feel good as well. My body feeling good is me feeling good too but in a longer feedback loop which doesn’t feel evident immediately. I will eat unhealthy food randomly over a week but only certain times a week. I don’t want to piss my body off. So every time I eat something that’s unhealthy, I tell my body to take care of it this time. And my body usually takes care of fewer messes I create. Hence, There will only be a few incidents when I act harshly with my body. Even when I do, there will be a difference in one action after the other, so that we both feel good.

  2. Then, I don’t want to exercise. But, my body doesn’t want to feel sore because of inactivity. I immediately put exercise as my top priority whenever my body feels even a bit sore. I have to be there for my friend when my friend needs me. On top of that, I’ll do exercise sparsely over the week without any schedule since it gives me a dopamine hit immediately afterwards. Previously, I would avoid doing a single physical exercise over months on end whenever I felt busy from my work, but can’t avoid like that now. My friend might just fuck me over if I don’t maintain my basic friendship. And that puts some obligation to exercise mentally.

    I had an interesting insight that came along with this change of weight for Player 2. In trying to change weights of the game for Player 2, the game redefined itself into a 2-player positive sum game. How can this be the case given that our goals conflicted each other ?

This happened because I thought eating healthy would be boring. Doing exercise would be boring. But, once you pass the tipping point, you actually start loving the dopamine hit. Now, it feels good to eat healthy. It feels good to not drink on subsequent days. And, my friends rarely push me to break my restraint. Now, it’s a positive sum optimization game. My body helps me have fun. I help my body feel good. We both feel good.

I have been spending time thinking why this fooling technique even works at all as well. It sounds so silly, to which, I too agree without a doubt. But, it has worked for me really well over past few years. I have kept my aggressive sinusitis in check, prevented myself from getting fat all over my stomach, and feeling back pain every now and then.

This positive sum game implies that we both try to optimize for each other’s best and take care of it to get net positive output for both players.

My reasoning to why this works comes from what modern researchers believe why meditation works. They note that whenever you meditate, you see your emotions from a 3rd person perspective, without identifying yourself to the same degree, as when you aren’t in meditation. We cannot observe facts with clarity when we feel overwhelmed. Thus, by decreasing the intensity of our emotions, meditation helps connect the dots that we were too clouded to see beforehand. This practice with my body, is in a sense similar, since it detaches me from my body so that I can’t do whatever I desire. That decreases the intensity of what I feel in short-term. Because what I desire in the short term is usually not what I want for myself in the long term, I needed to find a way to de-intensify the short term rewards similar to de-intensifying my overwhelming emotions. And the way is to treat my body as a foreign agent ( not me ).

item.content:
Procrastination

ID: 2e93fc98-6218-4630-8ff0-1d30c3f6849c

Problem 1: Immensity of work

  • You commit to wiping out an entire forest instead of actually starting to work with a single tree at the moment.

  • What happens?

    • Even before starting, the mental pressure of the whole big hill over you makes you more afraid even to start. You try to console yourself that you can do it in some later point as you don’t have the energy to do it now or some reason to justify not to do it now. The immensity makes it difficult even after days.

  • Solution

    • Break down a big task into as simple tasks as possible. Like breaking down a big rock into pebbles. The pebbles should be as simple as they can be such as setting up your environment and so on.

Problem 2: Fear of actual results

  • What happens?

    • You want to get gratification by saying: “I could have done that amazing task and I know I would be great at it”. You are taking this mental gratification as a justification for not doing the task at hand. Remember: “You can’t edit a blank page.”

  • Solution

    • If you think people will judge you for your results and you think it will make you feel bad. In fact, people don’t even care for most of us. Just because you have over 1000 friends on Facebook, hundreds of followers on Instagram doesn’t mean they are interested in you. People aren’t computers. Even the strongest of memories fade away: People have to have a grudge on you to remember small things that you failed even if you failed small. Will you care about them and not work?

Problem 3: Jumbled physical spaces

  • You watch movie, read and sleep on the same bed.

  • What happens?

    • You have no specific place that you can work on so that sitting on the space itself helps you commit to work you put off for a long time.

  • Solution :ATTACH:

    • Your mind’s accustomed to working things as automatically as you can. Creative people, players and even commonly us: We do things unconsciously upon being in different kinds of environment. Your brain’s amazing and does tasks on it’s own as much as it can. But these automatic tasks might not be favorable at instances. Your body understands to feel drowsy and sleepy when in bed; So when you feel like being the most productive person on the planet in your bed, your brain fails you miserably.

      So, instead of quarreling with the hundreds of years of evolution, take it to your advantage. If you separate spaces for your work, sleep and rest; now this habit of brain helps you to work when you are at physical space representing work: either it’s simple table and chair for you or an entire study room.

Problem 4: No actionable tasks

  • Even your planned tasks are vague and need more thinking.

  • What happens?

    • Your tasks need thinking even after you made the plan. Now you drown down the rabbit hole and the whole loop starts again.

  • Solution

    1. Two minute rule: Tasks that take two minutes now: just slash them out of your list. Your list is precious and needs to be as clean as possible. These two minutes task if ignored for now might take longer later on.
    2. Make tasks actionable: Don’t drown into thoughts again : I will do this or that and all of it. Make simple tasks that you can clearly see yourself working and start doing it.
    3. Start with something that you find best in that whole rock: a simple crystal you like. It might not be the first thing to do but to keep you on track and inspire you: it will be the best place to start.
    4. Plan tasks with actual schedule. Don’t even think of situations where you can compromise later. What if someone calls me for party? This is the worst thing you can do now. What happens and what to be done if such thing happens is to be taken care of at that very moment it happens. Don’t ever fall into that trap.

Problem 5: You are a perfectionist

  • You feel like you have to be the best out there and shouldn’t do something that’s not amazing.

  • What happens?

    • Being a perfectionist but realist at the same time helps but just making perfect imaginations of anything doesn’t help at all. Learn the art of the start. Be relentless to perfection but for god’s sake start with any output you can have.

  • Solution

    • We all want to have the best versions of ourselves to show to others. Noone wants to be seen weak or incapable. But it’s people who start with anything they have, improvise over time are the ones who accomplish the most. It’s okay to be afraid because it’s deep rooted in our brain from earlier times of evolution. It’s a social coping mechanism. People who weren’t accepted by society back in hunting days would die or be killed. We have changed but our brains are wired the same way. Don’t stress over it. Just give time to see people doing imperfect things. You can start by looking at works of your favorite YouTubers and movie stars so that you know people you thought are perfect now were not perfect from the very start. They improvised over time to be who they are now.

Problem 6: Tasks that need Internet

  • You start working with all your enthusiasm when a certain notification bell rings on your phone or you start with 10 minutes of Facebook time.

  • What happens?

    • You get lost searching for things on the internet related to your task and find at the end of the day that you spent a whole day watching YouTube videos and browsing Facebook or Reddit or anything you hadn’t planned for.

  • Solution

    • In today’s time, most of us can’t work without using internet. While all the media companies and businesses over internet are there to lure you to spend more time on their platform, it’s a very hard escape out of it. They have been studying our psychologies and preferences even those which we are not even conscious of. So, the best thing we can do is be aware. Be present at the moment. Have a stopwatch tick before you start using Internet or regular interval checks to at least know when you have plunged into it. Doing this simple act will change you over time. It’s not an overnight thing but it will create some significant changes.
    • Use site blockers: the stricter the better. Some cannot even be uninstalled after you activate them. Make sure to make it as difficult as possible to stop them. e.g. Trigger stopping it to deleting all your movies and music from your hard drive. Just giving some ideas.

Few Last Tips

  • Use Pomodoro technique if you like it. It helps make tasks look simple in terms of time to commit to tasks.
  • Use your morning to give a momentum for the day. Just accomplishing simple tasks as folding your bed or cleaning up your room can give you a feeling of gratitude and push you to break some more rocks ahead.
  • Getting Things Done is a nice way to organize your todo lists.
  • Try to make a weekly review of your todo list so that you know what are blocking you. You can do shorter reviews such as in 3 days. The faster the review time: the better the feedback loop. You know your problems better.

item.content:
A Reminiscence

Looking at this image, I find it funny how we change so much that we are no longer ourselves. I believed I was this way for as long as I can remember but alas with time: memories fade, people around you change and you no longer are the same person that you were before. This is the first page of my diary I made in my 9th grade. Looking at the aim I wrote in this diary, it feels so funny and grave misfortune that I had no idea about the storm of life that was about to burst upon me with all it’s might. I so foolishly believed life was all about being the best in exams. There’s a catch here though: the people I was around, the people who wanted me to have a bright successful life always came to me and said it: maybe thousand times or more. My teachers, my parents, my relatives and everyone that wished well for me. Either they didn’t know that life was so intricate and complex beyond you passing exams and being best out of it. I believed it to be the holy grail that would guide my life now.

Now, Walking along this path, I did what I believed. I became the best version of who I could be with what I had. Then the wind hit me hard in my face as I faced the winding road of life. There was no simple aim in anyone’s life. I was with my shield of being best in exams and in real life I was as naked as I could be. Now, the arrows hit me from all sides: arrows being just education and certificate doesn’t make you who you want to be. Life told me: You need to learn some life skills: hobbies that you can do when you are in pain so that you get lost in yourself, skills that you can at least earn some money for your expenses, ability to ask for what you want when you realize the world doesn’t give a damn about you and the fact that you have to go exploring the world rather than success and happiness coming to you by default.

The quote I wrote there seems amazing to me since myself in that state was all clear about his life and his path. Yet, that me knew what was going to happen with my life. For all these years, this quote has been the summary of my life. I feared ever trying to give 100% to anything. I always left when I felt it was finally up to the top. I felt an urge to back down when I saw the peak. It was never that I didn’t have the knowledge or the skills I needed, it was just I was afraid of falling on the way to the mountaintop. All this has come to me after 8 years. I wished I could write this letter to that me 8 years back.Would it have mattered? Would I have listened to myself? That’s a question that will forever remain.

I have gone through a horrible path to get out of this belief. I hope no child is taught that exams are the way to better life: life is much more than that. I hope noone has to go this long to realize their beliefs were a lie.

The darkness grew out of the worldly ways,

The stories of success,

The stories of failures,

The horrors of living,

The ephemeral life,

And the drive to thrive.

 

Now,

With a gasp it starts,

Slowly it finds it’s way

Creepy they are,

Creeping through me like swinging vines,

Stranded and clogged.

 

Walls of mind and tentacles of thoughts,

The war of the microcosm,

The dance of the devil form.

My bones are still the same,

My muscles undeformed,

But it feels like

The quarks inside them want some deadly transform.

 

Cold it is,

To fight with ownself.

Hard it is,

To break the chains of thoughts.

Pain it is,

To not understand anyone but ownself.

Peace it is,

To lay inside the box in peace

With tentacles of thoughts buried to the ground.

item.description:

Thought they made,

Of the day when their steps would be on the mountain peak,

Clear seem’d they, Of the goal they desperately seek.

The mountains of hope: deep and strong first,
